channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hezbollah Fires Rockets at Israel in Response to Killing in Beirut
item.description: Israel said it had fired back at militants involved in the rocket launches, but the exchange stopped short of a major escalation.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Rawan Sheikh Ahmad and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Smoke rising above Khiam, in southern Lebanon, after an Israeli bombardment on Saturday.

item.title: As Gaza Losses Mount Under Israeli Strikes, Proper Burials Are Another Casualty
item.description: “The lucky are those who have someone to bury them when they die,” Dr. Mohammad Abu Moussa, a radiologist at one Gaza hospital, said of those killed by Israeli airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Samar Abu Elouf and Yousef Masoud
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman and her daughters searching a cemetery for the graves of relatives during a truce in November in central Gaza.

item.title: Ukraine Says Russian Attacks Kill 11 Civilians
item.description: Ukrainian officials said missile assaults had struck private houses, trapping residents under the rubble, and that the dead included five children.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: State Emergency Service of Ukraine, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photo provided by the Ukrainian government showing rescue workers in Pokrovsk, in the Donetsk region, on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Patriot Defenses at Work: Shuddering Booms and Bursts of Light
item.description: The American-provided air-defense systems have helped Ukraine defend itself against Russian assaults, but Washington has warned that it will not be able to keep them supplied for much longer.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Damage in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, in December after Russia targeted it with a salvo of missiles.

item.title: After Niger Coup, U.S. Scrambles to Keep a Vital Air Base
item.description: After the generals took charge, the United States was forced to suspend operations at its most strategic military asset in sub-Saharan Africa. Restarting them won’t be easy.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Eric Schmitt and Carmen Abd Ali
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. Air Base 201 in Agadez, Niger, a vital military asset and the biggest construction job Air Force engineers ever undertook alone, has been mostly idle since the country’s coup in July.

item.title: In Indonesia, Democracy or Dynasty?
item.description: Critics say that hard-won progress toward democracy in Indonesia has been backsliding under Joko Widodo, a two-term president who was once a political outsider.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Gibran Rakabuming Raka, left, the elder son of President Joko Widodo of Indonesia, and Prabowo Subianto, the defense minister, greeting supporters in Jakarta in October.

item.title: Quebec Still Longs for Its Lost Hockey Team, a Nationalist Symbol
item.description: Ever since the Quebec Nordiques decamped in 1995, leaving a hole in the Francophone city, vote-seeking officials have vowed to bring them back. But younger voters may be starting to forget the team.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A junior hockey league team, the Quebec Remparts, in red, competing in an arena that was built for 370 million Canadian dollars, in the hopes of attracting an N.H.L. team.

item.title: Israeli Minister Proposes Plan for Postwar Gaza Amid Divisions
item.description: The plan exposed divisions in Israel’s war cabinet as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken returned to the Middle East on Friday in an effort to ease escalating tensions.
item.dc:creator: Roni Rabin, Euan Ward and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: Smoke billowing over Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, during an Israeli bombardment on Friday.

item.title: Putin Aims to Strengthen Russia’s Military by Easing Citizenship for Foreigners
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin is seeking to strengthen his military to fight in Ukraine while avoiding a potentially unpopular mobilization of Russians.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Russian recruits at a train station in Prudboi in September 2022. Russia imposed a draft of up to 300,000 reservists that month.

item.title: Terrorism in Iran Exposes a Vulnerability It Doesn’t Want to Admit
item.description: Even after the Islamic State took responsibility for deadly bombings, Iran’s government, facing public anger, blamed Israel.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of a victim of Wednesday’s terrorist bombing in Kerman, on Friday in Tehran.

item.title: Playing for Time, U.K. Leader Sets Up Chance of U.S. Election Overlap
item.description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak signaled that voters will go to the polls in the fall, around the time that the United States will be in the midst of its own pivotal vote.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain in Mansfield, England, on Thursday, where he said: “My working assumption is we’ll have a general election in the second half of this year.”

item.title: A Palestinian Man Vanished Oct. 7. His Family Wants to Know Who Killed Him.
item.description: Soheib Abu Amar, who lived in East Jerusalem, was captured by Hamas during its attack on Israel. His brothers spent weeks investigating what happened next.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abd Al-Mughani Abu Amar, left, and Mahmood Abu Amar, the brothers of Soheib, came to the area where the Nova music festival took place to retrace his last known steps.

item.title: Election Will Further Test Bangladesh’s Ailing Democracy
item.description: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina is expected to roll to a fourth consecutive term as the gutted opposition boycotts what it calls an unfair election.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: Election campaign posters hanging over a street, in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Thursday.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius, Olympic Athlete Convicted of Murder, Is Released
item.description: The South African sprinter, whose trial for the 2013 killing of his girlfriend drew intense global interest, served more than seven years in prison.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius before proceedings at the Pretoria Magistrate’s Court in 2013.

item.title: Arno J. Mayer, Unorthodox Historian of Europe’s Crises, Dies at 97
item.description: A Jewish refugee from the Nazis, he argued that World War I, World War II and the Holocaust were all part of a “second Thirty Years’ War.”
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: The historian Arno J. Mayer in 2013. He argued that both world wars and the Holocaust were the result of modern, liberal capitalism colliding with an entrenched European elite.

item.title: Boeing’s 737 Max 9 and the Alaska Airline Grounding: What to Know
item.description: Boeing faced new safety questions after an Alaska Airlines jet made an emergency landing when a hole opened in its fuselage in midair.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze, Keith Bradsher and Melissa Eddy
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:description: An Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 aircraft in Seattle in 2021.

item.title: Resolving New Year’s Resolutions
item.description: What does it take to finally make a resolution stick?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada’s Foreign Student Surge Prompts Changes, and Anxiety
item.description: As international students flock to Canada, the country is looking closer at ways to protect them against labor and financial exploitation.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students after taking a shuttle bus from downtown Timmins, Ontario, to the local Northern College campus. The institution has seen a significant uptick in foreign students in recent years, mostly from India, as domestic enrollment has waned.

item.title: Galaxies in the Early Universe Were Shaped Like Bananas, Study Suggests
item.description: Images from the Webb telescope suggest that newborn galaxies look weirder than expected. Exactly how screwy was physics at the dawn of time?
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: If You Wanna Mail My Letter, You Gotta Get Some Spice Girls Stamps
item.description: Royal Mail said on Friday that it was issuing a set of 15 stamps to celebrate the girl group’s 30th anniversary. The stamps will go on sale on Jan. 11.
item.dc:creator: Lola Fadulu
item.media:description: Royal Mail is issuing a set of 15 stamps to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the Spice Girls.

item.title: Hezbollah’s Leader Says It Would Not Negotiate Peace With Israel Until War in Gaza Ends
item.description: In a televised speech, Hassan Nasrallah addressed Israeli citizens directly, warning that they “will be the first to pay the price” unless the military action stops.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: A televised speech by Hassan Nasrallah, the head of Hezbollah, shown to Hezbollah supporters in Baalbek, Lebanon, on Friday.

item.title: Neo-Nazi Podcasters Who Called for Prince Harry’s Death Are Sentenced
item.description: The men, who were described by the police as “homophobic, racist, antisemitic, Islamophobic and misogynistic,” received eight- and seven-year sentences.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Christopher Gibbons, left, and Tyrone Patten-Walsh.

item.title: Out of Sight, Out of Mind No More
item.description: The Africa Cup of Nations and the Asian Cup, once seen as poorly timed intrusions by European soccer, may finally be getting the respect they deserve.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Mohamed Salah, off to Africa for a month.

item.title: Families of American Hostages Held in Gaza Release ‘Bring Them Home’ TV Ad
item.description: The 30-second spot is set to air on cable channels and during Sunday network news programs in the United States for the next several weeks.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear

item.title: Blinken Returns to Middle East as Tensions Grow With Israel
item.description: Details of a clash between the U.S. secretary of state and Israel’s prime minister point to the challenges ahead.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Antony J. Blinken, the secretary of state, plans to visit Israel and the West Bank headquarters of the Palestinian Authority during a visit to the Middle East.

item.title: Eurozone Price Pressures Edged Higher to End the Year
item.description: Inflation in the countries that use the euro rose to 2.9 percent in December, but the underlying rate continued a downward trend.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: A restaurant in Berlin, last year. The inflation rate in Germany rose at a slower-than-expected rate in December.

item.title: U.K. Rain Causes Hundreds of Flood Warnings and Travel Disruptions
item.description: In London, around 50 people were evacuated from rising waters. Heavy rain brought similar scenes to parts of France and Germany.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Unauthorized Settlement Surges in Occupied West Bank, Advocacy Group Says
item.description: Peace Now, which monitors settler activity in the West Bank, said it had recorded nine new outposts and several roads not authorized by Israel, fueling tensions in the area.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Damaged roads after Israeli raids in Jenin, in the occupied West Bank, last month.

item.title: The U.S. secretary of state begins a Mideast trip amid worries of broader conflict.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken departing for his Middle East trip at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland on Thursday.

item.title: North Korea Fires Artillery Near Border With South Korea
item.description: The South asked nearby islanders to seek shelter before it launched a military exercise in the disputed waters and chided the North for “threatening peace.”
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: South Korean marines patrolling Yeonpyeong Island in 2020. North Korea fired artillery into nearby waters on Friday.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: The threat of a regional war.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: People walk through the rubble of destroyed buildings following strikes on the town of Naqoura in southern Lebanon on Thursday.

item.title: Indonesia Train Crash Kills at Least 2, Official Says
item.description: Hundreds of passengers were evacuated from the crash near the city of Bandung. The cause of the accident was not immediately clear, and the authorities have opened an investigation.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Mike Ives
item.media:description: The Bandung Raya local train collided with the Turangga train in Cicalengka, Bandung, West Java province, Indonesia, on Friday.

item.title: Lebanese and Israelis Flee Homes Along Border Amid Fighting
item.description: More than 150,000 people have been driven from their homes on both sides of the frontier as Israeli forces clash with Hezbollah militants.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Roni Rabin, Hwaida Saad and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: An Israeli artillery unit firing toward a target in Lebanon from Israel on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Islamic State Claims the Iran Bombing
item.description: Plus the seven keys to longevity.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Sare Tajalli/ISNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by Iran’s state-run news media on Wednesday of the site of the explosions in the city of Kerman.

item.title: Education Dept. Official Resigns Over Biden’s Policies on Israel and Gaza
item.description: Tariq Habash, who is Palestinian American, said the Biden administration “does not value all human life equally.”
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bodies of Palestinians killed at Nasser Hospital, in the southern Gaza city of Khan Younis, in December.

item.title: White House Says North Korea Providing Russia With Ballistic Missiles
item.description: Russia has rebuilt its own domestic supply of cruise missiles, but to keep up with the intensity of the barrage against Ukraine, it has been turning to North Korea and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Kirby, a White House spokesman, said that a series of North Korean-produced missiles were fired into Ukraine from Russia.

item.title: Vatican Defends Gay Blessings, but Offers Critics Some Leeway
item.description: The clarification on a declaration issued in December seemed designed to soothe critics while also showing that this is the way forward.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Pope Francis leads the Angelus prayer on the World Day of the Poor in St. Peter’s Square at the Vatican in November.

item.title: Mike Sadler, Intrepid Desert Navigator in World War II, Dies at 103
item.description: Like a human GPS, he guided Britain’s first special forces across the vast Sahara for hit-and-run raids on enemy bases in the battle against Rommel’s forces.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

item.title: Winter Storm Traps Hundreds of Motorists Overnight in Sweden
item.description: Truck drivers and other motorists were locked in blankets of snow on a major roadway overnight after nearly 10 inches of snow fell within 24 hours.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson
item.media:credit: Johan Nilsson/TT News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The E22 roadway in Sweden on Thursday. The authorities said that rescue workers had evacuated everyone who wanted to leave their cars by Thursday afternoon.

item.title: Why London’s Tube Is Shutting Down Next Week
item.description: Large strikes by workers on the London Underground are expected to cripple the capital’s transportation network for several days.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Efren Landaos/Sipa USA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The London Underground system will be largely shut down for most of next week.

item.title: Iraq Condemns U.S. After Drone Strike in Baghdad
item.description: The attack, acknowledged by the Pentagon, killed a senior militant leader of an Iran-allied group with ties to the Iraqi government’s security apparatus.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The coffin of a Harakat al-Nujaba member being carried in Baghdad after Thursday’s strike.

item.title: Kim Jong-un’s Daughter Is His Likely Successor, South Korea Says
item.description: Kim Ju-ae has long accompanied her dictator father to important state events, like long-range missile tests and military parades.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by the Korean Central News Agency on Monday was said to show Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, with his daughter, Kim Ju-ae, in Pyongyang.

item.title: Experts See a Message in Chinese Balloons Flying Over Taiwan
item.description: Some analysts see the objects as a calculatedly ambiguous reminder to voters that Beijing is watching.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Folding a flag of Taiwan in the island’s capital, Taipei. The balloons from China do not appear to pose an immediate military menace.

item.title: A Trophy in Ruins: Evidence Grows That Russia Controls Marinka
item.description: Ukraine said it was defending territory behind the eastern frontline town. Its capture would be Russia’s most significant territorial advance in Ukraine in more than six months.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier along the front line near Marinka in August.

item.title: Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Deadly Bombings in Iran
item.description: The group, which has struck before in Iran, has a long history of division with the country.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Hwaida Saad and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Sare Tajalli/ISNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by Iran’s state-run news media on Wednesday of the site of the explosions in the city of Kerman.

item.title: Putin’s Drive to Rewrite History Snares a Retired Lithuanian Judge
item.description: A few years ago, Kornelija Maceviciene ruled against Soviet officers for a brutal crackdown on pro-independence protesters in her country in 1991. That has made her a target for a Russian court.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kornelija Maceviciene, 70, near the entrance of Vilnius District Court in Lithuania. “I really can’t figure out their logic,” she said of the Russian authorities. “The facts of the case are clear.”

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: A deadly blast in Iran.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mahdi Karbakhsh Ravari/Mehr News Agency, via Associated Press

item.title: Canada’s Boreal Forests Badly Damaged by Logging
item.description: A study finds that logging has inflicted severe damage to the vast boreal forests in Ontario and Quebec, two of the country’s main commercial logging regions.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portion of boreal forest in northern Quebec. A study found that commercial logging in Quebec and neighboring Ontario has caused the removal of 35.4 million acres of forest.

item.title: Killing of Hostages Leads Israelis to Question How Army Conducts Battle
item.description: Israel’s military said that soldiers who shot hostages, while they waved a white flag, violated its rules of engagement. Human rights activists say the rules are good, but enforcement is lax.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in December in northern Gaza.

item.title: Princess Mary of Denmark, Australia’s Homegrown Heroine
item.description: “I don’t recall wishing that one day I would be a princess,” Princess Mary told reporters. “I wanted to be a veterinarian.”
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Crown Princess Mary in 2023. She is admired in both her native Australia and her adopted country of Denmark for combining elegance of dress with a down-to-earth manner and embrace of progressive causes.

item.title: Israelis Fear Assassination of Hamas Deputy May Disrupt Hostage Talks
item.description: Israelis welcomed news that a top Palestinian militant had been killed, but feared that it might impede the release of hostages and kindle a broader war.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: A top Hamas official, Saleh al-Arouri, was killed in an explosion outside Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Attacks Heighten Fears of a Wider War for the Middle East and U.S.
item.description: The killing of a top Hamas leader in Lebanon and mysterious twin explosions in Iran heighten fears of a regional war that could draw in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Sare Tajalli, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Iranian state media showing emergency personnel near the blast site in Kerman, Iran.

item.title: Hezbollah’s Leader Pledges Revenge for Killing of a Hamas Leader in Beirut
item.description: “Yesterday’s crime will not go unpunished,” Hassan Nasrallah warned ominously, but he gave no specifics, saying he would speak again on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Hwaida Saad and Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, greeting supporters via video link during a highly anticipated speech on Wednesday. He said he would speak again on Friday.

item.title: Menendez Case Focuses on How Qatar Trades Its Riches for Clout
item.description: The tiny Gulf state has cultivated relationships with powerful people and institutions to raise its global profile, and to protect its interests.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, is accused of using his position to benefit Egypt and Qatar.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Blasts in Iran Kill Dozens
item.description: Plus, China shakes up its military.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Mehr News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph released by Iranian state media showed emergency personnel at the blast site in Kerman, Iran.

item.title: Israel Supreme Court Delivers Setback to Campaign to Remove Checks on Netanyahu
item.description: The country’s Supreme Court ruled to postpone the adoption of a new law making it harder to designate a sitting prime minister unfit for office, a direct blow to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Tel Aviv, in December.

item.title: Israel Says It Dismantled a Hamas Tunnel Under Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital
item.description: The Israeli military says the tearing down was done in November and that hospital wasn’t damaged in the process.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier in November near a stone-and-concrete shaft on the grounds of Al-Shifa Hospital, a sprawling complex in Gaza City.
